moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 c5 3. d5 b5 4. cxb5 a6 5: All the game started from this position, with White to move.
moves.8. bxa6 d6 9. Bc4 Bxa6 10. Bxa6 Nxa6: A fairly standard sequence of exchanges for this opening.
I have regained the gambit Pawn. The middlegame is even at this moment, with my spatial advantage balanced against White's passed Pawn. I have to convert my advantage into something tangible because if an end game is reached the passed Pawn becaomes a much larger advantage for White.
moves.15. Rb1 Nb6 16. b4 cxb4 17. Bxb4 Nc4: A few manuevers leave the position slightly simplified but still balanced.
moves.18. Qb3 Rc8: I'm trying to use the opened Q-side to my advantage by securing attacking routes.
moves.21. Bc3 Qa7: Trying to eliminate the passed Pawn and secure a material advantage.
moves.22. Nb5 Qa6: Still focusing on the QRP as I duck out of the Knight's attacking range.
moves.25. Ra1 Qd3: The tactics start to get complicated. Right now we are both trying to win each other's Knights.
moves.26. Na4 Qa6: I have to admit that here I didn't calculate everything 10 moves ahead, simply gambling that I would emerge with an advatage after the tactical knife-fighting came to a conclusion. Sometimes you have to grab the tiger's tail and hang on for the ride.
moves.27. Rxa3 Rc4: I'm momentarily behind in material. However, my trump card is a potential back rank mate.
moves.28. Nb2 Qxa3: Now after the exchange of Queens, White cannot capture the Rook (29 QxQ RxQ 30 RxR??? R-B8 ch 31 N-Q1 RxN mate.)
moves.29. Qxa3 Rxa3: Whie has to move his Rook away, and he does.
moves.31. Nd3 Rca2: The best move here for White is P-R3, eliminating the back rank mate threat. Instead, he blunders away any hope of dragging out the game.
moves.32. Rf1 Rxd3 33. h3: With his Knight gone, White chooses to resign here.
